thread.title: Wolves' players and fans perform Icelandic thunder clap after shock FA Cup win against Liverpool
thread.title_full: Wolves' players and fans perform Icelandic thunder clap after shock FA Cup win against Liverpool

author: Liam Corless
title: Wolves' players and fans perform Icelandic thunder clap after shock FA Cup win against Liverpool
text:
Sport Wolves' players and fans perform Icelandic thunder clap after shock FA Cup win against Liverpool Wolves produced the shock of this season's FA Cup so far with a well deserved 2-1 win at Anfield Share Wolves' players and fans do the Icelandic thunder clap after beating Liverpool (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Share Get Liverpool FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Wolves' players and supporters provided a throwback to last summer's European Championship as they performed the Icelandic thunder clap to celebrate their shock FA Cup win at Liverpool. 
Iceland international Jón Daði Böðvarsson led his Wanderers teammates over to the away end at Anfield to celebrate the impressive 2-1 victory. 
The thunder clap was a major theme throughout Euro 2016 as minnows Iceland defied the odds to reach the quarter-finals of the competition. 
Böðvarsson was part of the side that knocked England out at the last 16 stage of the Euros and he revelled in a second huge shock in seven months as his Wolves teammates came up with the goods on Merseyside. Jón Daði Böðvarsson leads the celebrations (Photo: Getty Images) 
Wolves were already two goals to the good when Böðvarsson was brought on as a 71st-minute substitute by boss Paul Lambert. 
Richard Stearman and Andres Weimann had ensured the visitors went into half-time with a 2-0 lead. 
Divock Origi stabbed home for Liverpool in the 86th minute but Wolves held on to book their place in Monday night's fifth-round draw. Richard Stearman headed home Wolves' opener (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Andreas Weimann rounded Loris Karius before making it 2-0 to Wolves (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Origi gave Liverpool hope but it was too little, too late (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp takes '100 percent of the responsibility' for FA Cup exit to Wolves 
"I said at the start of the game that I don't know any other way to play away from home," Lambert said after the match. 
"I said that we would try to attack and we got something to hang on to, but when you play here, you have to be big and brave with it. We had to handle the atmosphere. I thought we were excellent."
